awd_titl_txt: Cyber Service Training and Education at Norfolk State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cyber Defense Education and Training (C-DET) Scholarship Program offered by Norfolk State University (NSU) Information Assurance, Research, Education and Development Institute (IA-REDI) is a Federal Cyber Service: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program which is supporting three cohorts of undergraduate and graduate students in Information Assurance (IA).

Highly trained NSU IA-REDI faculty with expertise in information assurance are serving as instructors and mentors for the SFS Scholars. C-DET Scholars are engaging in cutting edge research projects and have access to state of the art equipment and IA industry leaders. The goals of this project include: (a) Guiding students in obtaining meaningful summer internships and permanent placement in the Federal Government. (b) Providing mentoring and close monitoring to ensure their success in the program. (c) Involving students in research projects and requiring presentations on IA topics to faculty and peers in an active seminar series. (d) Providing scholarship recipients with opportunities to interact with IA experts from industry and academia via guest lectures and industry tours. (e) Engaging scholarship recipients in organizations such as the Information Assurance Club, and competitions such as the Mid-Atlantic Regional Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition (CCDC) and the Digital Forensics Challenge (DC3).

The project is having an immediate impact on the cybersecurity capabilities of the federal workforce by providing graduates with security skills to federal agencies. NSU's Computer Science Department consists of approximately 300 undergraduate and graduate students of which 90% belong to various minority groups. The establishment of this scholarship program is having an immediate impact on increasing the number of trained IA professionals from under-represented groups entering the Federal Cyber Service program. The project is conducting IA awareness and education activities involving high school students through various departmental and university liaison programs.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report: Award Number 129247

 

The Scholarship for Service (SFS) Cyber Corps Grant enabled the PIs and Co-PIs at Norfolk State University (NSU) to recruit and retain twenty-three scholars. The recruited scholars were undergraduates and graduate students from NSU and other higher education institutions. The grant was active for the scholars from the Fall of 2011 through the Summer of 2022.

 

A total of five of the twenty-three scholars who participated in the SFS Program were recruited from Tidewater Community College (TCC). Four TCC Cohorts were enrolled at TCC when accepted into the SFS program. The Cohorts transferred to NSU and continued participating in the SFS program. One of the TCC students transferred to NSU and was accepted into the SFS program.

 

Full scholarships, books, stipends, and professional development were some of the grant's awards that assisted with retention of the program participants. The scholars were assigned, mentors. Seven graduate and sixteen undergraduate students participated in the SFS Program. Eleven students graduated with Master's degrees, and ten with Bachelor's degrees. Two SFS Scholars are in the Scholarship Phase of the program and are expected to graduate in spring 2023.

 

Twenty graduating scholars have found employment. One scholar who graduated with a Bachelor's degree and sought a Master's degree is actively seeking employment. Two undergraduate SFS Scholars who are graduating in spring 2023, are actively seeking employment.  

 

Of the twenty employed SFS Scholars, five SFS Scholars are in the Commitment Phase. Ten SFS Scholars are in the Monitoring Phase. Five SFS Scholars have completed their eight-year Monitoring Phase.

 

Dr. Jonathan Graham, PI, and Dr. Cheryl Hinds, Co-PI, established an Information Assurance (IA) Student Club at IC Norcom High School in Portsmouth, Virginia, facilitating bi-weekly meetings. The SFS Scholars participated in developing a cybersecurity program for IC Norcom students. 

 

The SFS Scholars met bi-weekly to discuss progress in the program. The SFS Scholars developed plans for participation in virtual and in-person SFS Job Fairs. The SFS Scholars managed competition registrations and preparation activities. Scholars participated in some significant competitions: The Virginia Military Institute (VMI) Cyber Fusion competition, the SysAdmin, Audit, Network, and Security (SAN) HBCU Cyberwars, and the National Cyber League (NCL) Cyber Competitions.

 

Scholars participated in travel, student research presentations, job fairs, resume writing, and interviewing skills. Scholars developed boot camps and participated in summer internships at various government agencies and approved private facilities and laboratories. The scholars continually received updates on training, internships, and job opportunities.  

 

The SFS Scholars invited various government departments and alumni to speak during the bi-weekly meetings. The speakers shared cyber security protocols with the scholars. The Alumni Scholars met (virtually) with scholars to discuss the transition from the Scholarship Phase to the Commitment Phase.  

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2023
Modified by: Jonathan M Graham
